'Sir Hugh Low', GCMG (10 May 1824 - 18 April 1905) was a British colonial
administrator and naturalist. After a long residence in various colonial
roles in Labuan, he became the first successful British administrator in the
Malay Peninsula. His methods became models for future administrators. He made
the first documented ascent of Mount Kinabalu in 1851. Both Kinabalu's
highest peak as well as the deep gully on the other side of the mountain are
named after him. EncyclopÃ¦dia
Britannica. Malaysia, Singapore & Brunei By Simon Richmond, Damian
Harper, Tom Parkinson, Richard Watkins Published by Lonely Planet, 2007; ISBN
1-74059-708-7, ISBN 978-1-74059-708-1
categories: Knights Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George
